1 a.definition: qualities (as adherence to duty or obedience to lawful authority) that together constitute the ideal of moral propriety or merit moral approval

sub_terms.b: something that is morally just [able to distinguish from wrong]

2.definition: something to which one has a just claim

sub_terms.a: a power, privilege, or condition of existence to which one has a natural claim of enjoyment or possession [the of liberty] [that all men…are endowed by their Creator with certain unalienable""] see also
sub_terms.b: a power, privilege, immunity, or capacity the enjoyment of which is secured to a person by law [one's constitutional]
sub_terms.c: a legally enforceable claim against another that the other will do or will not do a given act [the defendant may be under a legal duty…to exercise reasonable care for the plaintiff's safety, so that the plaintiff has a corresponding legal to insist on that care "W. L. Prosser and W. P. Keeton"]
sub_terms.d: the interest that one has in propertya claim or title to property often used in pl. [a security interest is not enforceable…and does not attach unless…the debtor hasin the collateral ""] [leasing mineral] see also
sub_terms.e: the interest in property possessed (as under copyright law) in an intangible thing and esp. an item of intellectual property [obtained publishing]

3.definition: a privilege given stockholders to subscribe pro rata to a new issue of securities generally below market price
